keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign applicants who require H-1B visas due to the increased cost of these visas under President Trump's proposed $100,000 fee.
The H-1B visa program allows U.S. companies to hire skilled foreign workers and is crucial for filling high-demand technical roles, especially in tech and e-commerce sectors.
Walmart, as the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and is significantly affected by the policy shift.

The proposed $100,000 fee on H-1B visas is intended to reduce perceived abuse of the program but may deter companies from hiring skilled foreign workers, impacting innovation and business competitiveness.
Skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B visa approvals, are particularly affected by this policy change.
This shift reflects a broader trend where major corporations are adjusting hiring strategies in response to government immigration policies with potential ripple effects across the U.S. economy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on these high-skilled work visas. The policy change reflects growing corporate sensitivity to immigration regulations, especially as skilled professionals from India—historically the largest group of H-1B applicants—are most affected. While the Trump administration claims the fee targets abuse of the H-1B program, economists and businesses argue it undermines competitiveness and talent acquisition, with significant implications for innovation and job creation in sectors like tech and e-commerce. This shift illustrates how national immigration policy can directly influence corporate hiring and labor markets, affecting both workers and global business competitiveness.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
